bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 1. Walked to Cambridge and read my 30th: Lecture— Heard at 11. A Lecture of Mr: Farrar— Experiments upon air—& with the Air Pump— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— Declamation at 2— Best we have had yet— Returned home immediately afterwards— On the way, I was overtaken by Mr: Lincoln the Lieutenant-Governor, who was coming from Worcester, and by whose invitation I took a seat with him in his Curricle— The day was excessively warm. Mr: C. Foster called on us this Evening.

2. I went to the Boston Bank, at the request of Mr: Jackson, and being out, was a couple of hours at my office— Mr: Allen the Sheriff invited me to dine with him, which I did— There was Mr: Lincoln the Lieutenant Governor—Mr: Tudor, judge Dawes, Mr: Jos. Russell and Mr: Tucker— Walking in the Evening I met Mr: Degrand, who came home with me, and we played several games of Chess together— Catherine Johnson pass’d the Evening with a young party at our neighbour Foster’s.

3. A Sleepless night; owing altogether to my own fault— Went with all my family to meeting, both parts of the day— Heard Mr: Nurse this morning; and Mr: Buckminster in the afternoon— Buckminster preached as usual an excellent Sermon— Took a couple of turns this Evening in the Mall— Read and wrote as much as I could in the course of the day.

4. Independence day— And our second boy, John’s birth day— My father came into town, and my wife & children, with Catherine Johnson went out in the Carriage to pass this day and night at Quincy— By invitation from the Governor and Council I attended them at the Senate chamber, and from thence to the Brattle Street Church, where we heard prayers read, by Mr: Buckminster— The Company returned to the Council-chamber and partook of a cold Collation— At twelve two processions again started from the State-house—one went to hear the town Oration, delivered by Mr: Andrew Ritchie; the other, a Republican party, went to dine at Charlestown— I heard Mr: Lowell’s prayer at the old South-Church, and then came home— Dined at the Governor’s, with a party of nearly thirty Gentlemen— Mostly Officers, civil or military— I came home with my father— Then went, and pass’d half an hour with a company of young republicans, from whom I had received a written invitation— Returned (as it rained) in a Carriage, which they had engaged for me— Then Went and spent an hour at Mr: S. A. Otis’s—after which my father returned home with me and lodges at my house— Mr: Ames died at 5 this morng:

5. My wife and family, returned from Quincy, with my second boy John very sick— I attended my father all the morning—visited with him, Mr: Jonathan Mason—Mr: Bowdoin—Mr: James Lovell, who was from home—Mr: Parkman; who was also absent— As was Mr: W. Smith— Then we were at my Own Office and afterwards at Mr: Shaw’s— We also went round the new-built parts of the town—India Wharf and Broad-Street— We dined at Mr: S. A. Otis’s— W. Smith junr: was there— My father returned this Evening to Quincy— Mr: Ripley here this Evening— John is again quite sick.

6. A number of Gentlemen met yesterday morning at the State-house, and agreed to make a funeral procession for Mr Ames, and chose Mr S. Dexter to deliver an Address on the occasion at the chapel Church this afternoon— They sent to Dedham for the body, and the family, who were all brought to be displayed in public and after the ceremony sent back to Dedham again. The procession was formed, from the houses of Mr: C. Gore—Mr: J. Gore and Mr: G. Cabot— I attended in this procession as one of the Officers of the College— The Church was very much crowded— The Address which was nearly an hour long was all that could be expected from a discourse so extemporaneous— There was also a short ode performed, written by judge Dawes— It was about 7. in the Evening when the Ceremony was over— Came home with the Ladies Mrs: Adams quite unwell— Club this Evening at Mr: Tyng’s.

7. Day at home writing, at my 33d. Lecture, which I finished— Our child John continues very ill—to a distressing and alarming degree— Walked this Evening in the Mall, where I met Mr: De Grand— Susan Adams came in from Quincy

8. Walk’d to Cambridge this morning; and read my 31st: Lecture.— Attended the Lecture of Mr: Farrar; which was upon the thermometer, Barometer & various other philosophical instruments.— The Corporation had a meeting; and sent me an invitation to dine with them— I was however obliged to attend the declamation at their dining hour— The junior Class, concluded, and the Sophomores commenced— There were only two Speakers, and both performed very well— I afterwards went and sat half an hour with the members of the Corporation who were still at dinner— I then walked home— Spent the Evening in reading. On my return from Cambridge, on Fridays I usually find myself too much fatigued to write for the remainder of the day. John is still very unwell

9. A heavy and steady rain which continued almost the whole day through, confined me to the house untill the Evening, when I walk’d three or four turns in the Mall— I was steadily employed in reading and writing on my 34th: Lecture—which I began— Our child John, appears to be this day a little better.

10. Dr: Waterhouse called here this morning just as we were going to breakfast.— He told me some of the persecutions which he is enduring at the College— He was going to Charlestown— As he went away my eldest boy, George, who had followed me attending him to the door, leaned against the Venetian-blind door, which opening by his weight, he pitched forward, rolled down the steps untill he came to the lowest which is of stone; and struck the back of his head against it, so as to raise a large contusion in the space of five minutes— This symptom was soon after followed by Sickness at his Stomach—faintness—and sleepiness— We were excessively alarmed, and sent immediately to Dr: Welsh— However the Child after laying half an hour on the bed, with immediate and continual application of vinegar to the bruise, recovered, and appears to have received no material injury. The Dr: when he came did not think it necessary to bleed him— In the afternoon we all went to Meeting, & heard Mr: Ware, whose Sermon was occasional on the Death of Mr: Ames.— It rained at intervals the whole of this day— And as we were coming home, we were obliged to stop a short time at Mr: J. Foster’s in School-Street— Susan Adams went to Mr: W. Smith’s, with his daughter Hannah.— Mr: Shaw pass’d an hour with us this Evening— I read and wrote as much this day as I was able— But the accident of my child had almost unhinged me for any thing— I am ashamed of my own weakness on this and the like occasions; and I pray for fortitude from above.

11. I enter this day upon my forty-second year.— I employed it from early in the morning, untill the dusk of Evening very assiduously writing, at my Lecture, and reading— The day was dull and rainy, untill towards Night; when the sky cleared and the Sun “with farewell sweet” made his appearance— I walked nearly an hour in the Mall— The return of my birth-day, is one of the Seasons which call on me for reflection— In the course of the last year I have been called by my duties as a Citizen and a Man to act and to suffer, more than at any former period of my life— To my duties I have stedfastly adhered— The course I pursued has drawn upon me much obloquy, and the change of parties in the State, with an accumulated personal malignity, borne me both on my father’s and my own account, by those who rule the State, produced in the first instance the election of a Senator to fill my place after the 3d: of March next— This election was precipitated for the sole purpose of specially marking me— For it ought in regular order not to have been made untill the Winter Session of the Legislature— They also pass’d Resolutions enjoining upon their Senators a course of conduct, with which neither my judgment could approve, nor my Spirit brook— I therefore resigned my seat— For my future prospects I have no reliance but on the disposer of Events— For the past I have the testimony of a good Conscience; and a firm belief that I have rendered essential service to my Country.

12. I had occasion to go out this morning, and for a short time attended the United States Circuit Court, sitting at Faneuil Hall, and the Court of Common Pleas, sitting at the Court-House— I was also at my own Office and some others— The rest of the day at home engaged altogether upon my Lecture— Walk’d with the Ladies in the Mall, this Evening.

13. Being called out again this day, and having several visitors in the course of it, I neither read nor wrote for my Lectures— My brother came into town, dined with us; and took out our son John with him at Night.— Mr: Boylston also dined with us. Mr: John Gray called here, this morning, and Mr: Bowdoin and Mr: G. Sullivan towards Evening— I attended the Club at Dr: Warren’s.— Walking with the Ladies we met Mr: Degrand, who came home & pass’d the Evening with them.

14. I attended this morning the U.S. Circuit Court sitting at Faneuil-Hall, and heard part of a capital trial for a murder committed on board a vessel in the island of Grenada— Afternoon at home, writing at my Lecture— Mr: De Grand called on me, and I took George, and we bathed at the alms-house wharf. The Ladies pass’d the Evening at Dr: Welsh’s, where I went with George, to take them home.

div.p: 15. I walk’d to Cambridge and read my Lecture 32. at 10 this morning.— Then spent an hour in the Library. Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s—and at 2. attended the Declamation— There were eleven performers, and the performances were very good— I walk’d home; and from the heat and fatigue of the day, I could employ the remainder of it, only in reading— I read several of Swift’s Drapier’s Letters; and perceive something of the address with which they are written— Evening walk in the Mall.

16. At 6 this morning, I went with Mr: De Grand, and my George, and bathed at the alms-house wharf— Mr: DeGrand returned and breakfasted with me— The day was excessively hot— My father sent a Chaise into town this afternoon, and I went out to Quincy with George— John was already there, and continues very ill— He is however rather better than when he went out, and we propose to let him pass the Summer in the Country.

17. This was one of the warmest days I ever experienced. Heard Mr: Tuckerman both parts of the day, and he dined at my father’s— A thunder-gust was coming up during the time of service in the afternoon; which was very long; and it came on very violent just as we came out of meeting.— It was heavy proportionably to the heat of the last three days. The Evening was clear— Mr: Beale & Mr: Greenleaf were at my father’s— I read little— But just looked into Harris’s Hermes.

18. Returned with George to Boston this morning in the Stage— Left John apparently better, and with Spirits lively. On our way we saw traces of the Storm, indicating greater violence than we had experienced— We found it had struck Dr: Lathrop’s Meeting-House in Boston— By the oversetting of a boat in the harbour there were four persons drowned, of whom were my Leaywright, our baker, and his son— I spent the day at home, but in the Evening called at the Athenaeum to look over Gray’s Memoria Technica— Sat there an hour with Mr: Shaw— Met on my return Mr: DeGrand with whom I had made an engagement to bathe this Evening, which I had forgotten. The weather cooling, towards Night.

19. Engaged the whole day in writing for my Lecture, on the subject of Memory, and in reading. Cicero—Herennius—Rogers—and Tooke’s Diversions of Purley—Part 2.— I did not go out of the house untill the Evening— And then walk’d nearly an hour with the Ladies in the Mall— Met Mr: DeGrand there; and he walk’d part of the time with us.

20. Walk’d this morning down to the market, and pass’d the remainder of the day at home— Reading a little; and writing upon my Lecture 35.— It was an industrious day.— The Club was this evening at my house; attended by Messrs: Davis, Elliot, Gray, Howard, Buckminster, Smith and Spooner.

21. I attended the Dedication of the new Meeting-house, of Mr: Emerson’s Society, which is removed from Cornhill into Summer-Street. Mr: Buckminster, Dr: Eliot, and Dr: Lathrop were the performers— Mr: Emerson himself preached a short Sermon— The rest of the day I was employed upon my Lecture— Read very little— Walk’d with the Ladies in the Mall, in the Evening.

div.p: 22. Walk’d to Cambridge, and read my 33d: Lecture— Mr: John Appleton was at Dr: Waterhouse’s, and attended— Mr: S. Codman was also there.— I attended Mr: Farrar’s Lecture, which was upon Optics— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s with Mr: Nicholls the tutor— Declamation at 2.— They continue to perform very well— On my return home I was overtaken by Mr: Jonn: L. Austin, and rode a short way with him— Walk’d the remainder— Read at home, the rest of the Drapier’s Letters, and something in Tooke’s diversions of Purley.— Evening with the Ladies at Mr: W. Smith’s— Where were Mr Otis’s, and Dr: Welsh’s families.

23. Mr: Loud was here this morning, and I went with him to my Office— At Noon I called on Mr: DeGrand, and saw the operation of his Belier Hydraulique, imported from Marseilles, and said to be an invention of Montgolfier— After dinner, I took George with me, and went out to Quincy with Mr: Loud— My Brother was expected to have returned this Evening with his wife and children from Haverhill but did not.

24. Sleepless Night— Heard a Mr: Clark, a young man, who is keeping school at Braintree; and who is just commencing his performances in the pulpit— Mr: Whitney was himself there in the afternoon— I walk’d down and pass’d a couple of hours at Mr: Quincy’s, in the Evening. He came part of the way back with me— I read part of a volume of Lord Shaftesbury; and part of a pamphlet of Mr: Spence; entitled Britain Independent of Commerce.

25. I returned from Boston this morning with George, in the Stage, and pass’d the day at home; chiefly writing—finished my 35th: lecture— We had a company of near forty ladies and Gentlemen here at tea, and the Evening.— I had some conversation with Mr: Dexter on the subject of Education.

26. I called upon Mr: De Grand, just before dinner, and examined the Construction of his Belier Hydraulique. Walk’d about half an hour this Evening in the Mall— The rest of the day I was confined at home by the weather. Rain great part of the day— I began my 36th: Lecture, with which I intend to close the course.

27. I pass’d this forenoon principally at my Office; but I find that I cannot yet spare the time from my Lectures— Was at Mr: Hall’s Office; and at the Fire and Marine Office— Chief Justice Parsons and Mr: William Gray, were discussing the Embargo, in the Suffolk Office.— The Afternoon I wrote in my chamber untill dusk— Walk’d in the Mall with the Ladies— And attended the Club at Mr: Buckminster’s— It was fully attended.

28. This day, I pass’d at home, and employed it, at my proper occupation— Our youngest child is again very sick— My Mother was in town, and was here this afternoon at tea— Evening walk in the Mall— I read besides Quinctilian & Cicero:—a part of Swift’s History of the four last years of Queen Ann.

div.p: 29. Walked to Cambridge this morning, and read my 34th: Lecture— There was I think more Company from abroad, than I have ever before seen— I dined at Dr: Holmes’s, and at 2. left his table to attend the Declamation— There were twelve performers, and most of them had long pieces— The exercise was an hour and a half long, which made the students somewhat weary, and disorderly— It was almost five O’Clock when I reached home— Rainy Evening confined us all at home— Charles is yet very unwell.

30. Employed the whole day, at home— All the Morning in writing for my Lecture. But after dinner, having finished the perusal of Swift’s History of the four last years of Queen Anne’s reign, my curiosity was excited to pursue the Story to a later period; and taking up the volume of Smollett which embraces that portion of time I was entirely absorbed in it untill the failure of day-light brought me to a pause.— In perusing the violent struggles of those contending factions, I could not but remark how much these times here resemble those— And reflect how much more the future is likely to resemble them in their worst features— I did not this day go out to Quincy— The agricultural Society dined at my father’s.

31. Heard Mr: Emerson, both Morning and Afternoon—with Mrs: A. Catherine and George— The Morning Discourse was on the existence of a God— That of the Afternoon upon the superiority of the Christian over the Jewish Dispensation Both very good Sermons.— Walk’d with the Ladies over the Common, and to the top of Beacon-Hill— I read again in Smollett an account of the first years of George the first’s reign— Read also Swift’s History of England, address’d to Count Gyllenborg— Something in Walker, and Massillon’s Sermon, on the respect due to religion from the great.
Day. As the last Month.
